The idea would be to build a universal family policy that treats support for parenting not as targeted aid, but as a fundamental investment in equality and collective well-being. The central axis is the establishment of a public early childhood service, universal and entirely free. This measure must be accompanied by a reform of parental leave, lengthening it and making it strictly parity-based and mandatory for both parents, complemented by a policy of reducing working time without loss of salary. The objective is to remove the economic barriers that weigh on families by also guaranteeing free access to culture and leisure for children. Thus, this would ensure that the choice to have children no longer results in economic precariousness or in a setback for equality between women and men, while ensuring the full flourishing of children.

The idea would be to move from a mosaic of occasional aids to an integrated and universal family policy, aiming both to reverse the demographic trend and to unlock the potential of women's labor. The pillar of this scheme is a single universal allowance, strengthened and modulated to encourage the activity of both parents. The main effort will focus on removing the economic barriers to parenthood, by making nurseries free for modest incomes and by introducing a reimbursement system for a wide range of educational, cultural and childcare expenses. In parallel, a reform of parental leave will promote a more balanced sharing of responsibilities, in order to neutralize the impact of motherhood on women's careers. Thus, this would make it possible to create an economic and social environment where starting a family is no longer an obstacle to professional and financial fulfillment, but a life project supported by a structural commitment of the community.

question: How can equitable and effective access to the healthcare system be ensured for the entire population?

propositions.value: The idea would be to conceive health no longer as an isolated national competence, but as a European public good, by building a genuine Health Union to guarantee equal access to care. The right approach is to pool strategic capacities by creating a large European public institute for the research, production and distribution of medicines and vaccines. This autonomy would rely on joint purchasing mechanisms to control costs and on the promotion of open patents to stimulate shared innovation. Thus, this would make it possible to reduce inequalities, to prepare the Union for future health crises and to guarantee every citizen effective and equitable access to treatments.

The idea would be to guarantee an effective and citizen-centered healthcare system, strengthening it through structural investments and pragmatic cooperation. The right approach is to significantly increase investments in public health and to reinforce cross-border collaboration, notably in the prevention of epidemics. The priority is to fund screening campaigns and the fight against addictions, while promoting well-being through sport. Any action must imperatively respect the fundamental rights of persons and preserve the sovereignty of States in the management of their healthcare system. Thus, this would make it possible to build a more resilient healthcare system capable of facing future health crises, while guaranteeing access to quality care without ideological conditioning or infringement of individual freedoms.

The idea would be to move beyond national logics by founding a genuine European Health Union, where access to care is no longer an economic variable but a fundamental right guaranteed to all. The right approach is to make health a shared competence, to ring-fence health investments by excluding them from budgetary constraints, and above all to create a European public infrastructure for research and production of essential medicines in order to control prices and address market failures. This would make it possible to ensure strategic health security for the continent, to put an end to the geographic lottery in access to treatments, and to build resilient and truly universal public health systems.

The idea would be to refocus the health system on the concrete needs of citizens by guaranteeing rapid, local access to care. The absolute priority is to reduce waiting lists by restoring the full range of routine services and screenings. To achieve this, territorial medicine must be strengthened and the numbers of doctors and caregivers significantly increased. At the same time, access to care will be facilitated by expanding medical services exempt from the co-payment, thereby reducing costs for patients. This approach will be based on a comprehensive revision of the national health plan to make it more effective and responsive. Thus, this would make it possible to offer an equitable response across the entire territory and to ensure that every citizen receives the necessary care in a timely manner.

The idea would be to guarantee effective access to care by relieving pressure on the hospital system and redirecting it toward local and preventive care. The proper approach is to remove the barrier to entry to medical studies by abolishing the numerus clausus, replacing it with a selection process at the end of a first semester open to all. At the same time, the reduction of waiting lists will be ensured by increasing the capacity of the public health service and by better integrating the contracted private sector. Emphasis will be placed on strengthening primary care and home care, while guaranteeing patients' freedom of therapeutic choice. Thus, this would make the health system more responsive and accessible, ensuring the renewal of generations of caregivers and bringing the provision of care closer to the real needs of citizens in their territory.

The idea would be to break with the logic of weakening and commodification of the health system in order to reaffirm its character as a universal public service, entirely financed by the community. The central axis is a massive reinvestment plan in infrastructure and personnel, financed by national solidarity. The correct approach is to end the two-tier system by removing all tax advantages for private insurers and by integrating private practice doctors into the public service. Priority must be given to strengthening local primary care and to an ambitious prevention policy, in order to address the causes of diseases upstream. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee the effectiveness of the right to health for all, to reduce territorial and social inequalities in access to care, and to build a resilient system centered on the well-being of the population rather than on profitability.

The idea would be to rebuild the health system to overcome the weaknesses revealed by the crisis, moving from a care-based approach to a global health strategy. The central axis is a recentralization of strategic governance to guarantee a homogeneous set of services and put an end to territorial disparities. Priority will be given to strengthening a local network, integrating primary care and social support, while an emergency plan will reduce waiting lists with guaranteed maximum waiting times. A new national prevention agency will steer crisis preparedness. Thus, this would ensure effective and equitable access to care, with sustainable financing aligned with European standards.
